metadata.case_name: Aravali Golf Club (Haryana Tourism Corporation) v. Respondents (Plaintiffs)

facts.text: Plaintiffs-respondents appointed as Mali (gardener) on daily wages in 1989 and 1988 respectively by defendant-appellant Aravali Golf Club run by Haryana Tourism Corporation.
In 1989, plaintiffs told to perform duties of Tractor Drivers though no post of tractor driver existed.

Plaintiffs continued to be paid wages for post of Mali for a number of years, then on recommendation of Head Office, paid wages of tractor driver on daily wage basis as per rates recommended by Deputy Commissioner.
Plaintiffs worked as tractor drivers for about a decade.
Services of plaintiffs regularized against post of Mali in 1999, no post as tractor driver.
Plaintiff No.1 filed Writ Petition No.6216/1991 for regularization; High Court directed representation against termination, restrained termination till decision.
Representation by plaintiff No.1 on 1991-05-02; informed on 1991-05-14 no post of tractor driver, case to be considered when sanctioned.
Plaintiff No.1 paid wages of tractor driver from August 1990 to 1999-05-11 on daily wage basis.
Plaintiff No.2 engaged as Mali w.e.f. 1988-09-01, regularized as Mali on 1999-05-11.
Despite representations, grievance not redressed; plaintiffs filed civil suit in April 2001 claiming regularization as tractor drivers.
Trial Court dismissed suit holding no post of tractor driver, plying tractor part of Mali job in Golf Club.
First Appellate Court (Additional District Judge, Faridabad) accepted appeal, set aside trial court decree, directed sanction of tractor driver post and regularization of plaintiffs.
High Court Single Judge in R.S.A. No.666/2006 dated 2006-02-17 affirmed First Appellate Court, held post should be created, no hitch, dismissed second appeal holding no substantial question of law.
No sanctioned post of tractor driver in establishment, undisputed.

legal_issues.text: Whether courts can direct creation of posts and regularization of employees against newly created posts where no sanctioned post exists.
Limits of judicial power and separation of powers; whether judiciary can perform executive/legislative functions like creating posts.

petitioner_arguments.text: No sanctioned post of tractor driver exists, hence no question of regularization thereon; plying tractor is part of Mali duties.
Courts cannot direct creation of posts, which is executive/legislative function involving economic factors.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Separation of powers; precedents like Indian Drugs Pharmaceuticals Ltd. v. Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: Trial Court finding of fact on no sanctioned post not disputed.

respondent_arguments.text: Working as tractor drivers since 1989/1990, entitled to regularization as tractor drivers despite initial appointment as Mali.

court_reasoning.text: No sanctioned post of tractor driver, undisputed; courts cannot direct creation of posts as it is executive/legislative prerogative.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Creation of posts involves economic factors; courts lack jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Directions by lower courts to create posts and regularize beyond jurisdiction; set aside.
Extensive reasoning on judicial restraint, separation of powers; judiciary must not encroach on executive/legislative domains.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judges cannot cross limits in name of judicial activism; must exercise restraint.

holdings.text: Courts cannot direct creation of posts or regularization against non-existent posts.
Judiciary must exercise restraint and not perform executive/legislative functions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Drugs & Pharmaceuticals Ltd. v. Workmen of Indian Drugs & Pharmaceuticals Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Courts cannot encroach into executive domain.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.C. Chandra v. State of Jharkhand
Tata Cellular v. Union of India
Ram Jawaya v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Constitution differentiates functions; no absolute separation but no assumption of others' functions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Asif Hameed v. State of Jammu & Kashmir
precedents_cited.relevance: Organs must function in demarcated spheres; judicial review limited.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Deoki Nandan Aggarwal
V.K. Reddy v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Judges should not play role of law makers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suresh Seth v. Commissioner, Indore Municipal Corpn.
precedents_cited.relevance: Court cannot direct legislature to make law.
Pendency of cases shows judiciary's own delays.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Expanded scope in judicial activism; but ordinarily for legislature/executive.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments of High Court and First Appellate Court set aside; Trial Court judgment upheld; suit dismissed.

key_quotes.text: The Court cannot direct the creation of posts. Creation and sanction of posts is a prerogative of the executive or legislative authorities and the Court cannot arrogate to itself this purely executive or legislative function.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In the name of judicial activism Judges cannot cross their limits and try to take over functions which belong to another organ of the State.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Judges must exercise judicial restraint and must not encroach into the executive or legislative domain.
key_quotes.speaker: court
